Award.AwardTitle: What Controls Mafic Eruption Style? The Causes and Consequences of Coupled Vesiculation and Crystallization Kinetics in Ascending Basaltic Andesite Magmas
Award.AbstractNarration:
What controls mafic eruption style? The causes and consequences of coupled vesiculation and crystallization kinetics in ascending basaltic andesite magmas.

Explosive eruptions involving mafic magmas pose important implications for hazards near active volcanoes. In particular, Strombolian eruptions produce large volumes of fine ash, high ash plumes, and large dispersal areas that may severely impact surrounding populations. Numerous studies suggest that explosivity is related to expulsion of gases from ascending, decompressing magmas that in turn depends on porosity-permeability properties of the magma and fragmentation style. In an attempt to elucidate the degassing process and its effect on eruptive style, it is proposed to investigate experimentally the development of permeability in experimentally decompressed mafic silicate melts with particular focus on the role of crystallization in mafic magmas as a control on eruptive style. Specifically, how does syn-ascent microlite crystallization influence development of connected vesicle networks and the percolation threshold, and how do these factors influence gas separation in the conduit and transitions in eruptive style? Hypotheses to be tested include: [1] Are crystal number densities related directly to decompression rate (i.e., due to rapid crystallization of hydrous mafic melts during vesiculation)? 2) Is melt permeability inversely related to magma viscosity? 3) Does decompression足driven crystallization change the percolation threshold (i.e., by limiting bubble expansion or by spatial control on bubble placement)? 4) Does decompression rate affect the style of mafic eruptions by controlling degassing efficiency and the depth and efficiency of syn足eruptive crystallization? These questions will be investigated via decompression experiments on synthetic basaltic andesite melts similar in composition to those erupted at Okmok volcano (Alaska), and with both pure water and mixed H2O足CO2 fluid phase to examine the influence of CO2 on crystallization and vesiculation kinetics. The experiments will be compared with natural samples from the mid足Holocene Middle Scoria Okmok volcano, which produced violent strombolian to subplinian and vulcanian eruption deposits. A ?permeameter? will be constructed to measure permeabilities of both experimental and natural samples to estimate percolation thresholds, and the results will be used to model gas segregation and fragmentation during explosive mafic eruptions.

Broader Impacts: This project will support a PhD student, and undergraduate student assistant at UAF. A new link will be forged with the UAF Alaska Native Science and Engineering Program (ANSEP) with the aim to hire Alaska Native undergraduate student(s) to perform research for the project. The project will also involve international collaboration with volcanologist Kathy Cashman (University of Bristol). The PI?s association with the Alaska Volcano Observatory also facilitates application of this research to assessment of volcanic hazards related to violent mafic eruptions at active volcanoes in Alaska and Cascadia. Development of new research equipment in the UAF Experimental Petrology lab will also enhance the infrastructure at UAF and provide new equipment that could fill research needs beyond geology and volcanology studies, including applications in other physical sciences and engineering disciplines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The United States is home to more than 100 active volcanoes, most of which are located in Alaska and the Cascades region. Explosive eruptions create ash clouds, ash fall, and pyroclastic flows that can threaten aircraft, people, and infrastructure even when the volcanoes are located in remote places. Volcanoes with lower silicon dioxide (SiO2) content magmas, such as basalt and basaltic andesite, often erupt quietly and produce lava flows. However, they can also erupt violently and produce ash and pyroclastic flows that can be very hazardous to people living in volcanically active regions in the United States. Basaltic andesite magmas crystallize as they rise to the Earth’s surface, causing gas bubbles to form. The resulting eruption style, quiet or explosive, is dependent on how easily the magma can release the building gas pressure as it rises. Volcanologists need to know what physical processes control magma degassing so we can understand what causes quiet effusion of lava versus violent explosions that create hazardous ash. It is possible that crystals forming in basaltic andesite magmas may influence their ability to degas, explaining why they have generally lower eruption intensities. This study examined the mechanical influence of crystals on how easily gas can escape from basaltic andesite magmas. Our goal was to experimentally determine whether crystal content influences how explosive an eruption might be and how transitions in eruption style from less to more intense, and vice versa, might be explained. This research applies to many volcanoes that can produce explosive eruptions in Alaska, the Pacific Northwest, and elsewhere in populated regions around the world.

 The research project involved recreating tiny parcels of basaltic andesite magma using high pressure and temperature experimental equipment located at the University of Alaska, Fairbanks (UAF). The rock samples were melted at pressures (1500 bars) and temperatures (1025 Celsius) typical for magma storage in the crust. The experiments were then dropped in pressure at a controlled rate to simulate magma rise to the surface during an eruption. After the experiment ended, the samples were prepared for analysis of gas permeability, gas volume fraction, and the sizes and shapes of bubbles and crystals using analytical equipment at UAF. The results were then used to assess how easily basaltic andesite magmas can degas when they contain different amounts of crystals.

 Our research produced results that have not been observed before. Experiments composed of high viscosity rhyolite to lower viscosity basaltic andesite melts with very few crystals all become permeable and degassed when gas bubble volumes were greater than 60 to 70 percent of the total, even though the melt viscosities differed by several orders of magnitude. This means that magmas with small numbers of crystals should behave similarly despite large differences in their SiO2 composition. As crystal content increases, crystals mechanically influence how bubbles connect together and cause magma to become permeable and degas at significantly lower gas volume fractions than crystal free experiments. It is possible that crystallization during magma ascent could modify degassing enough to cause a shift in eruption style and reduce eruption intensity. This helps volcanologists understand more about the inner workings of basaltic andesite volcanoes, and the conditions that lead to quiet versus explosive eruptions.

 The research conducted for this grant was performed by graduate and undergraduate students at the University of Alaska, Fairbanks, supervised by the PI. Although one student performed much of the work for her PhD thesis, the project involved the efforts of three other graduate students and three undergraduate research assistants. The students all received training in running the experiments, performing the analyses, building lab equipment, and creating published and submitted journal articles. An important aspect to this work is a new research collaboration between the University of Alaska and the University of Bristol in the United Kingdom. This collaboration continues to provide international research experiences for UAF graduate students. The project contributed new lab equipment to the University of Alaska that is available to other researchers in the geosciences and engineering fields. The PI developed and delivered new course content in her undergraduate volcanology courses based on the outcomes of this project. Specifically, the PI developed a section for her GEOS 406 Volcanology course that uses samples and results from this project in a lecture, lab, and homework “module” to teach students about the physics and chemistry of magma degassing as it relates to eruption style.
